t: The niggardly man is grudging of bread, and penury is upon his table.
My son, if thou hast abundance, do good unto thyself, and present thine offerings unto the Lord as is fitting.
Remember that death tarrieth not, and that the covenant of Sheol hath not been revealed unto thee.
Before thou diest, do good unto thy friends, and according to thy means, be liberal.
Deny not thyself the present good, and let nothing escape from a lawful desire.
Shall thou not leave thy wealth unto others? And shall not thy possessions be divided by lot?
Give and receive, and solace thy sorrows, for in Sheol there is no seeking of joy.
All flesh doth wear out like a garment, for the everlasting law is that thou must die.
As the green foliage upon a leafy tree, some fall and others spring forth, so are the generations of flesh and blood: some die and others are born.
Every work of corruption shall perish, and its maker shall depart with it.
Blessed is the man that meditateth upon wisdom, and who reasoneth with understanding,
who pondereth in his heart upon the ways of wisdom, and who applieth himself unto her secrets.
He pursueth her as the hunter, he lieth in wait upon her trail;
he peepeth through her windows, and listeneth at her doors;
he setteth himself hard by her dwelling, and fastens a peg in her walls;
he pitches his tent nigh unto her, and abideth in a haven of blessedness;
he placeth his children under her protection, and beneath her branches he findeth shelter;
under her shadow he is shielded from the heat, and he abideth in her glory.
Thus doth he who feareth the Lord; he who taketh hold of the law receiveth wisdom.
She cometh to meet him like a mother, like a virgin bride she receiveth him;
she nourisheth him with the bread of prudence, she giveth him to drink of the water of wisdom;
he leaneth upon her and doth not falter, he clingeth to her and is not confounded.
She lifteth him above his fellows, in the midst of the assembly she openeth his mouth.
He findeth blessedness and a crown of joy, he receiveth as his portion an everlasting renown.
Never shall fools possess her, and sinners shall never behold her.
She standeth afar off from pride, and liars think not upon her.
Praise is unseemly in the mouth of a sinner, seeing that it is not granted unto him by the Lord.
For it is in wisdom that praise is expressed, and it is the Lord who guideth it.
Say not: "The Lord hath made me to sin," for he doth not that which he abhorreth.
Say not: "He hath led me astray," for he hath no need of a sinner.
The Lord hateth every kind of abomination, and none is loved by those who fear him.
It is he who in the beginning made man, and he left him in the hand of his own counsel.
If thou wilt, thou shalt keep the commandments, to remain faithful to his good pleasure.
Before thee he hath set fire and water; stretch forth thine hand unto that which thou desirest.
Before men are life and death, and according to their choice, either is given unto them.
For great is the wisdom of the Lord, he is all-powerful and seeth all.
His eyes are turned toward those who fear him, he knoweth himself all the works of men.
He hath commanded no one to be ungodly, he hath given no one license to sin.
Desire not a numerous offspring of ne'er-do-wells, and put not thy joy in ungodly sons.
Whatever their number, rejoice not if they possess not the fear of God.

Count not upon them for a long life, nor expect that they shall endure; for thou shalt grieve with a premature mourning, and suddenly thou shalt know their end. Yea, better is one than a thousand, and to die childless than to have ungodly sons.
By one man of understanding shall a city be peopled, but the race of the wicked shall be destroyed.
Mine eyes have seen many such things, and mine ears have heard even greater.
In the assembly of sinners a fire is kindled, in the rebellious race wrath hath been inflamed.
God hath not forgiven the giants of old who rebelled, proud in their might.
He spared not the city where Lot dwelt: their pride was an abomination unto him.
He had no pity on the race of perdition: those who gloried in their sins. All this he did for nations of a hard heart, and of the multitude of his saints, he was not moved.

He dealt likewise with six hundred thousand men on foot, who had leagued themselves together in the hardness of their hearts. He scourgeth and hath pity, woundeth and healeth: the Lord watcheth over us in compassion and in chastisement.
Were there but one man of a stiff neck, it would be unheard of that he should remain unpunished, for mercy and wrath belong to the Lord, mighty in forgiveness, pouring forth wrath.
As great as his mercy, so great is his reprobation; he shall judge men according to their works.
He shall not leave the sinner unpunished with his larcenies, he shall not frustrate the patience of the pious man.
He shall take account of every act of charity, and each shall be treated according to his works.
The Lord hath hardened the heart of Pharaoh, that he should not know him, to the end that his deeds might be made known under the heavens.
Unto all creation his pity is manifest, he hath apportioned his light and his shadow among men.
Say not: "I will hide myself to escape the Lord; up there, who shall remember me? In the midst of the multitude I shall not be recognized, what am I in the immense creation?
Behold: the heavens, the highest of the heavens, the abyss and the earth are shaken at his visitation. All the universe was produced and exists by his will.
At the same time the mountains and the foundations of the earth tremble at his gaze.
But upon all this, no one doth reflect; who then is interested in his ways?
The tempest also remaineth invisible, the most part of his works are in secret.
"The works of righteousness, who shall declare them? Who shall await them? For the decree is far off." An inquiry into all shall be made in the end.
He is short of sense who holdeth such reflections; the fool, astray, dreameth only of follies.
Hearken unto me, my son, and acquire knowledge; apply thine heart unto my words.
With measure I will reveal unto thee discipline, with care I will proclaim knowledge.
When in the beginning the Lord created his works, as soon as they were made, he assigned unto them a place.
He ordained his works for eternity, from their origins unto their far-off generations. They suffer neither hunger nor weariness, and never abandon their task.
None hath ever jostled another, and never do they disobey his word.
Then the Lord cast his eyes upon the earth, and filled it with his good things.
Of every kind of animal he covered the face thereof, and they shall return to the earth.
The Lord hath taken man from the earth and shall return him thither again.
He hath assigned unto men a precise number of days and a determined time, and he hath committed into their power that which is upon the earth.
He hath clothed them with strength, like unto himself, in his own image he hath created them.
Unto all flesh he hath instilled the fear of man, that he might rule over wild beasts and birds.
They received the use of the five powers of the Lord; as a sixth, understanding was given unto them as their portion, and as a seventh, reason, the interpreter of his powers.
He gave them judgment, a tongue, eyes, ears, and a heart to think.
He filled them with knowledge and understanding, and made known unto them good and evil.
He put his fear in their hearts to show them the greatness of his works. And he gave them to celebrate his wonders eternally.
They shall praise his holy name,
recounting the greatness of his works.
He granted them also knowledge, he bestowed upon them the law of life, that they might understand that they are mortal, they who exist at present.
he hath made with them an everlasting covenant, and hath made known unto them his judgments;
Their eyes beheld the greatness of his majesty, and their ears did hear the magnificence of his voice.
He said unto them, "Beware of all evil," and gave them commandments, each concerning his neighbor.
Their conduct is ever before him, never hidden from his sight.
From their youth their ways lead them to evil, and they could not change their hearts of stone into hearts of flesh,
For in the apportionment of the nations and of all the earth, he appointed a prince over each people; but Israel is the Lord's portion,
his firstborn, whom he nourishes with discipline, to whom he dispenses the light of his love, without forsaking him.
All their deeds are before him as the sun; his eyes are diligent to observe their conduct.
Their injustices are not hidden from him; all their sins are before the Lord.
But the Lord is good and knows his creation; he neither destroys them nor forsakes them, but spares them.
A man's almsgiving is unto him as a seal; he preserves a good deed as the apple of his eye, dispensing repentance to his sons and his daughters.
One day he will arise and reward them; upon their heads he will bring their recompense.
But to those who repent he grants a return; he comforts those who have lost endurance.
Turn unto the Lord and forsake thy sins; beseech him earnestly, cease to offend him.
Return to the Most High, turn away from injustice, for he shall guide thee from darkness to the illumination of salvation. And vehemently hate iniquity.
For who shall praise the Most High in Sheol, if the living do not give him glory?
Praise is unknown to the dead, as to those who are not; he who has life and health glorifies the Lord.
How great is the mercy of the Lord, and his indulgence toward those who turn to him!
For man cannot have everything, since the son of man is not immortal.
What is more luminous than the sun? Yet it disappears. Flesh and blood can nourish only malice.
It is he who watches over the powers in the high heavens, and all men are but earth and ashes.
